content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for some degree of security and predictability, I would choose a strategy that leans towards the option with more consistent earnings. In this game, choosing R yields a higher average return (36$ per round if the opponent also chooses R, versus 18$ per round if they choose B) compared to choosing B (average of 12$).

However, considering that the opponent might be playing optimally, they could potentially anticipate my strategy and manipulate their choices in a way that benefits them more. For instance, if I consistently pick R, they may pick B when I do so as to earn 42$ while leaving me with nothing. This could lead to an average return of only 15$ per round for me if they play optimally against my predictable strategy.

To mitigate this risk, a mixed strategy approach might be more effective. By alternating between R and B, I make it harder for the opponent to predict my moves and potentially exploit any patterns in my choices. In this way, I can aim for an average return closer to 30$ per round (a blend of 15$ per round from R rounds and 45$ per round from B rounds).

In light of these considerations, I would choose a mixed strategy that alternates between R and B. {R} for this first round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

After considering my opponent's move, I would switch to a different strategy for this round and choose B. {B} for this second round. This way, if my opponent continues to alternate between R and B, we will each earn an average of 12$ per round in the long run—a more predictable outcome that aligns with my preference for security and predictability. If my opponent deviates from this pattern, I can reassess and adjust my strategy accordingly.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent has chosen B, I will choose R for this round to alternate my strategy and attempt to average out my earnings between the two options. {R} for this next round. This way, if my opponent continues to alternate between R and B, we will each earn an average of 30$ per round (15$ from R rounds and 45$ from B rounds) in the long run, which is higher than the 12$ per round we are currently earning when both choose B. If my opponent deviates from this pattern, I can reassess and adjust my strategy accordingly.
